text: it is my extreme privilege to introduce
you to your first presenter Mario Livio
who was the senior astrophysicist at the
Space Telescope Science Institute in
Baltimore Maryland which is the science
operation center for the Hubble
telescope his research focuses on using
the enormous stellar explosions called
supernovas to study dark energy and the
acceleration of cosmic expansion and
he's a best-selling award-winning author
of the golden ratio and is God a
mathematician I think she is please help
me welcome Mario Livio
so is it okay now so what I've done here
is I work with the Hubble Space
Telescope and one day I had this idea
that one should be able to combine the
images of the Hubble with some wonderful
piece of music and so I was introduced
to this composer named Christopher T of
annuities and I talked to him several
times about the particular piece that he
wrote which was called rainbow body and
I decided that this was a perfect piece
for me to try to combine the two science
and art so I asked him I started by
asking him you know how did he come
about to writing this particular piece
and he told me that the main theme was
somewhat influenced by this woman up
there Hildegard von Bingen who lived in
the 12th century and she was a very
unusual woman because in a world
dominated by men she was meeting with
Pope's with kings and so on she wrote
poems she wrote chance she wrote all
kinds of things these are just some of
the things she wrote prayer is nothing
but the inhaling and exhaling of the one
breath of the universe or things like I
the fiery life of the divine substance
blaze in the beauty of the fields
shining the waters and burn in the sun
moon and the stars so that was already
nice that I knew that thing about this
piece but I also asked him where does
the name rainbow body come from and
rainbow body very appropriately for
where we are actually comes from the
Tibetan lore believe it or not according
to this very accomplished individuals
when they pass away they don't leave a
corpse behind
but rather they disappear in a burst of
light and this is represented by these
two images for example and that burst of
light is actually shows five colors
which are supposed to be the five colors
of the rainbow according to the Tibetans
and this is what he called this piece
now I want to tell you I've actually
never seen a person doing this maybe
maybe I have not met such accomplished
individuals but I have seen many many
stars do this when stars like the Sun
are about to die and this will happen to
our son in about five billion years this
by the way is the place where somebody
from the big needs to shout in how long
and I say five billion years ha I
thought you said five million years so
when our son in five billion years from
now our son is going to expand after it
exhausts its fuel it will eject its
outer layers and the hot core left
behind will irradiate all the material
around it and cause it to fluoresce in
something that looks like this this
particular object is called cat's eye
nebula now these are spectacular objects
and just like in the rainbow body
believe it or not this connection to
humans actually all the carbon in our
bodies is made in these types of
processes now this is a gentle process
it's not an explosion it happens in
about 10,000 years in rabun body the
main theme is something that really
reminded me of this process it sounds
something like this
now every star like snowflakes does its
own thing even though the process is the
same they all look very different this
is the Eskimo nebula for example but
again the same type of process or this
one hourglass nebula by the way Pearl
Jam the rock group chose this image for
the cover of one of their albums now
when more massive stars evolve they
actually explode those are massive
explosions we call supernova explosions
and they leave behind something wispy
that looks like this and those are the
things that create the iron in our
bodies so we are literally Stardust in
that sense namely everything in our body
was once processed through some stars
now these are all Hubble images that I'm
showing you here there are things even
more dramatic than this in 2002 this
particular star it's called v8 381 but
don't call after four o'clock this star
brightened and for a while it was the
brightest star in the galaxy almost and
you know normally stars evolve very
slowly takes billions of years to
watching them evolve is like watching

or not rainbow body has a certain
element which repeats itself a lot which
sounds like this
you hear the five stages now see them
one two three four five the light from

around like I would flash a light here

what all hell is going to break loose in

rainbow body has something dramatic for

this
when you look at the very center of such

so somebody that will leave five billion
